message_1: A factory produces light bulbs and claims that their bulbs have an average lifespan of 900 hours with a standard deviation of 100 hours. A random sample of 36 bulbs is taken to test the claim. What is the probability that the sample will have an average lifespan of less than 880 hours?
message_2:
To find the probability that the sample will have an average lifespan of less than 880 hours, we can use the z-score formula for a sample mean:

z = (X - μ) / (σ / √n)

where X is the sample mean (880 hours), μ is the population mean (900 hours), σ is the population standard deviation (100 hours), and n is the sample size (36 bulbs).

z = (880 - 900) / (100 / √36)
z = (-20) / (100 / 6)
z = (-20) / (16.67)
z = -1.2

Now, we need to find the probability that corresponds to a z-score of -1.2. We can use a standard normal distribution table (also known as a z-table) to find the probability.

Looking up the z-score of -1.2 in the z-table, we find a probability of 0.1151 (or 11.51%).

So, there is an 11.51% probability that the sample will have an average lifespan of less than 880 hours.
